video.title: Python Variables and Data Types Tutorial

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: In this tutorial you’ll learn what variables are in Python and how to work with the most common data types: integers, floats, strings, booleans, lists, tuples, and dictionaries. These concepts are the foundation of every Python program.

sections.title: What is a Variable in Python?
sections.content: A variable is a name that refers to a value stored in memory. You use variables to store data and reuse it later in your code. In Python you don’t need to declare the type explicitly—the interpreter infers it from the value you assign.

sections.title: Declaring Variables
sections.content: You create a variable by choosing a name and assigning a value with the = operator.
sections.code:
x = 5
message = "Hello, World!"
# x holds an integer value (5)
# message holds a string value ("Hello, World!")

sections.title: Overview of Python Data Types
sections.content:
Python has several built-in data types. The most common ones for beginners are:
- integers (int)
- floating point numbers (float)
- strings (str)
- booleans (bool)
- lists (list)
- tuples (tuple)
- dictionaries (dict)
In the next sections we’ll look at each of these with short examples.

sections.title: Integers and Floats
sections.content: Integers are whole numbers (…, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, …). Floats are numbers with a decimal point. You use them for anything involving counting or measurements.
sections.code:
a = 10      # integer
b = 20.5    # float
print(a)
print(b)

sections.title: Strings
sections.content: Strings are sequences of characters: text, words, or sentences. You can use single or double quotes to define them.
sections.code:
name = "Alice"
welcome = 'Welcome to Neetechs'
print(name)
print(welcome)

sections.title: Booleans
sections.content: Booleans represent truth values: True or False. They are often used in conditions and comparisons to control the flow of a program.
sections.code:
is_active = True
is_admin = False
print(is_active)
print(is_admin)

sections.title: Lists
sections.content: Lists are ordered, changeable collections of items. You can add, remove, and modify elements at any time.

sections.title: Tuples
sections.content: Tuples are similar to lists, but they are immutable: once created, their contents can’t be changed. They’re useful for fixed collections of values.

sections.title: Dictionaries
sections.content: Dictionaries store data as key–value pairs. They’re perfect for representing structured data like a student, product, or configuration object.

sections.title: Basic Operations with Numbers
sections.content: You can perform arithmetic operations directly on integers and floats. Here are the four basic operations:
sections.code:
num1 = 10
num2 = 5
print(num1 + num2)   # addition
print(num1 - num2)   # subtraction
print(num1 * num2)   # multiplication
print(num1 / num2)   # division (float result)

sections.title: Common String Operations
sections.content: Two common string operations are concatenation (joining strings together) and slicing (taking a part of a string).
sections.code:
greeting = "Hello"
name = "Alice"
message = greeting + ", " + name + "!"   # concatenation
print(message)
print(message[0:5])   # slicing -> 'Hello'

sections.title: Working with Lists
sections.content: Lists are dynamic—items can be added or removed at runtime. This makes them very flexible for managing collections of data.
sections.code:
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
fruits.append("orange")      # add an item
print(fruits)
fruits.remove("banana")      # remove an item
print(fruits)

sections.title: Working with Dictionaries
sections.content: You can update values or read them using their keys, which makes dictionaries great for labeled data.
sections.code:
student = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
student["age"] = 26            # modify a value
print(student)
print(student["name"])        # read a value

sections.title: Summary and Next Steps
sections.content: You’ve learned what variables are in Python and how to use the most important built-in data types: integers, floats, strings, booleans, lists, tuples, and dictionaries. Practice by creating your own variables and combining these types in small examples—for example, a simple contact list or a student database. In the next tutorial, we’ll build on this by exploring control structures such as if statements and loops.
